Gather (b)Berries(/b) and (b)Fruit(/b) during summer and save longer lasting resources such as (b)Cured Meat(/b), (b)Dry Fish(/b), and (b)Grain(/b) for winter.
(b)Avoid(/b) targeting (b)healthy adult(/b) animals when hunting in the (b)early game(/b), as they are hard to kill and might fight back.
Use (b)work areas(/b) in conjunction with (b)resource limits(/b) to automate your settlement as much as possible.
Don't (b)expand(/b) too fast if you don't have the (b)infrastructure(/b) to feed your people.
(b)Domestic animals(/b) need to be (b)fed(/b) and given (b)water(/b) in (b)winter(/b). Avoid having too many if you can not maintain them.

In (b)paleolithic(/b) hunter-gatherer societies, (b)conflict(/b) was (b)rare(/b), as the human populations were sparse. From the (b)neolithic onward(/b), though, you really need to be prepared for (b)battle(/b).
It's (b)hard(/b) to achieve (b)large populations(/b) in the (b)early(/b) eras. Only with farming and other technologies will you be able to sustain a large settlement.
Make sure that when (b)winter(/b) comes you have plenty of (b)non perishable food(/b) in storage, otherwise starvation will be a serious problem.
Getting someone to go to rivers, lakes, or wells to (b)collect and store water(/b) is way more (b)efficient(/b) than having your people go drink away from the settlement every time.
You can (b)customize(/b) the panels at the top of the screen by clicking on the (b)+(/b) buttons next to them.
(b)Pivot the camera(/b) around a point by pressing both (b)pan(/b) and (b)rotate(/b) keys at the same time.
In (b)standard(/b) difficulty, raider (b)technology(/b) will (b)match(/b) your current era, so be careful before advancing too quickly.
In (b)hardcore(/b) difficulty, attackers will advance their (b)technology(/b) at their (b)own pace(/b), so you should not take too long to progress through the eras.
You can tell your people to go (b)rest(/b) or (b)shelter(/b) by selecting them and (b)right clicking(/b) on a (b)structure(/b).
When people get (b)hurt(/b) there is a chance they might catch an (b)infection(/b), which could be fatal.
You can give (b)commands(/b) to your people by (b)selecting(/b) them and (b)right clicking(/b) on the terrain or on an object.
You can (b)command(/b) your people to (b)sprint(/b) to a location by selecting them and (b)double right clicking(/b) on the terrain.
You can (b)quicksave(/b) the game by pressing (b)F9(/b).
(b)Double click(/b) on a plant, being or building to select all similar (b)nearby entities(/b).
You can press the (camera_center_town_key) key to move the camera back to town.
You can hold the (hunter_selection_key) and (fighter_selection_key) keys while dragging the mouse to select people with (b)hunting(/b) or (b)fighting(/b) tools only.
You can use (b)primal vision(/b) mode to highlight (b)work areas(/b).
Dawn of Man

In (b)Dawn of Man(/b) you guide a settlement of ancient humans in their struggle for survival. You will have to (b)hunt(/b), (b)gather(/b), (b)craft tools(/b), (b)fight(/b), research new (b)techs(/b) and face the challenges the environment will throw at you.
Hunting

Using specialized tools, your people can hunt animals in order to obtain (b)food(/b) and (b)resources(/b) from them. To start a hunt, select an animal in the environment and then click on the (b)hunt button(/b). Depending on the difficulty of the prey, and the availability of tools, a certain number of people will go after the animal. Animals will react in different ways when being hunted: some will try to (b)escape(/b), others will protect their offspring or will try to (b)retaliate(/b). You can control the hunt in more detail by selecting one or more adults and right clicking on a target animal.
Farming

Farming allows you to automate the production of (b)food(/b), and sustain more people in your settlement. You can plant a variety of (b)crops(/b), then harvest and process them to feed your people. Crops are usually planted in winter or spring and collected in summer or autumn. It is important to plant a (b)variety(/b) of crops as diseases can easily wipe out all the individuals of a single species. In order to maximize the efficiency of the harvest, make sure you have enough (b)Sickles(/b) around. Of all crops, (b)cereals(/b) are probably the most important, they are not only a source of (b)Grain(/b) but also (b)Straw(/b), which is a vital resource both as a building material and also as animal food.
Defense

One of the keys to survival is to defend your settlement against hostile (b)animals(/b) and (b)raiders(/b). During the (b)stone age(/b), the main threats are wild animals and sporadic bands of raiders. Make sure you have enough weapons and people to defend the settlement against them. In the (b)metal age(/b) things will get more serious, and large bands of attackers will try to destroy your settlement. It is highly recommended that you build (b)fortifications(/b) and (b)defensive structures(/b). At any time you can trigger an (b)alert(/b) in the defense panel, your people will then run back the settlement, get the best weapons available and man the towers.
Human Status

Humans have (b)health(/b), (b)nutrition(/b), (b)hydration(/b), (b)rest(/b), (b)temperature(/b), (b)stamina(/b) and (b)morale(/b) indicators that reflect their current status. When an status indicator is low, a (b)warning sign(/b) will appear on top of that person, highlighting what's wrong with them. Having sub-optimal status will make your people less effective, and eventually cause them to die. You need to monitor your people at all times and make sure their needs are fulfilled.
Health

This is a measure of the physical health of a person. If it goes too low, the human will die. (b)Health(/b) slowly recovers by itself in normal circumstances, unless the other status indicators are low or the human is affected by a (b)condition(/b).
Nutrition

This is a measure of how well fed a person is. If it goes too low, (b)health(/b) will start to drop, and the human will eventually die. (b)Nutrition(/b) can be recovered by eating food, which can be obtained from a variety of sources.
Hydration

This is a measure of how thirsty a person is. If it goes too low, (b)health(/b) will start to drop, and the human will eventually die. (b)Hydration(/b) can be recovered by drinking from a (b)river(/b), (b)lake(/b), (b)well(/b), or (b)stored water(/b).
Rest
This is a measure how tired a person is. If it goes low, humans will be less effective at work. (b)Rest(/b) can be recovered by sleeping in a (b)Tent(/b), (b)Hut(/b) or (b)Roundhouse(/b).
Temperature

This is a measure of the body temperature of a person. If it goes too low, (b)health(/b) will start to drop, and the human will eventually die. To warm themselves up, humans can wear thicker clothing or shelter inside a (b)Tent(/b), (b)Hut(/b) or (b)Roundhouse(/b).
Stamina

This is a measure of how out of breath a person is. if it goes too low, the human won't be able to run. It is an important factor in combat or when hunting. (b)Stamina(/b) recovers automatically when idle.
Morale

This is a measure of the psychological health of a person. If morale goes low, they will be (b)less effective at work(/b). Keeping morale high is therefore critical to the success of your settlement. Morale can go down due to (b)hunger(/b), (b)deaths(/b), or performing (b)tedious tasks(/b), such as farming or carrying heavy loads. Morale is increased by visiting one of the morale recovering structures like the (b)Skull Pole(/b), (b)Totem(/b), (b)Menhir(/b), (b)Dolmen(/b) or (b)Stone Circle(/b). More advanced morale structures recover more morale. A person has to wait a period of time before recovering again from the same type of structure, so it is important to build a variety of these. Later in the game you can also produce (b)Beer(/b), which recovers a lot of morale, but needs to be made from Grain.
Knowledge

You can earn (b)knowledge points(/b) in the game by achieving various goals: • Reaching larger populations • Building different types of structures • Hunting different types of animals • Acquiring the various resources • Killing raiders • Unlocking milestones • Surviving more years You can then use these points to unlock new (b)techs(/b), which allow you to advance your settlement and be able to sustain larger populations.
Crafting

Your people can craft a variety of resources in the settlement's structures. To craft a resource, select a (b)crafting structure(/b) and click on a recipe. If the resources are available, one of your people will craft it. You can also right click on a recipe to toggle (b)continuous production(/b). When enabled your people will automatically produce the resource until the (b)resource limit(/b) is reached.
Expanding

If your (b)welfare(/b) is high enough and you have enough capacity in your settlement, new people will come and join it, and your women will give (b)birth(/b) to new children. You can increase your housing capacity by building (b)Tents(/b), (b)Huts(/b) or (b)Roundhouses(/b). The frequency of migrant arrivals depends on your (b)welfare(/b) and (b)prestige(/b). The fertility of your people also depends on your (b)welfare(/b) level.
Resource Limits

Resource Limits are a powerful way to automate work in your settlement. You can set a (b)resource limit(/b), then mark a recipe for continuous production or place a work area: your people will keep on collecting or producing that resource until the limit is reached. When resources are consumed and the amounts fall below the limit again, your people will go back to work. You can set any limit to 3 types of values: (b)Infinity(/b). There's no limit to production, it will continue as long as there are materials available. (b)Fixed amount(/b). Sets a limit defined by a specific number of units. Production stops once the number of units of that particular resource reaches the value. (b)Population percentage(/b). Sets a limit defined by a percentage of the current population. Setting a percentage limit is useful to avoid having to constantly adjust the limits as the population changes. Note that limits only affect work areas and automatic crafting, if you explicitly give an order, the limit is ignored.
Resource Decay

Most resources and tools (b)decay(/b) over time, decay is also accelerated when tools are used. Resources stored inside a structure, decay slowly. This is especially important for food, as it can mean the difference between having a good winter or massive starvation. Some foods (b)decay very quickly(/b) like: Fruit, Berries or Raw Meat and Raw Fish. Some foods (b)last a lot longer(/b) like: Grain, Cured Meat and Dry Fish. Your people will try to eat the food that is going to decay sooner in order to preserve more durable food for later.
Workload

The (b)workload(/b) of your settlement is the ratio between the amount of tasks your people are trying to do, and the total amount of people. If you ask your people to do too many things at once, they will be overworked, and will have trouble prioritizing the right tasks. It is your job do make sure the amount of work to do is reasonable and proportional to the manpower available. You can use the (b)tasks(/b) and (b)activity panels(/b) to see what your people are up to and how many of them are available to work.
Human Roles

Depending on the age of your population they are able to perform different tasks: (b)Children(/b). They can carry light resources around, one at a time, and do basic tasks that don't involve the usage of tools. (b)Adults(/b). They are the most efficient of your people, they can carry a larger number of resources and perform any task. (b)Elderly(/b). They can perform the same tasks as adults, but have less health and can carry less resources.
Work Areas

Setting (b)work areas(/b) allows you to automate many of the (b)collection(/b) and (b)mining(/b) tasks in your settlement. After you place an area for a given resource, people will keep collecting the resource within that area until the (b)resource limit(/b) is reached. By default only one person at a time will work in a particular area, but you can increase their number in the selection panel.
Foods

There are are different (b)types of food(/b) that your people can consume, it is important to understand the differences between them. (b)Raw Fish(/b). Available all year long, every river or lake bank contains a certain amount of fish, once you exhaust it you need to wait for it to replenish. You can use the (b)Food Dryer(/b) to convert (b)Raw Fish(/b) to (b)Dry Fish(/b), which lasts a lot longer. (b)Raw Meat(/b). You can hunt animals for their meat all year long, but in winter there will be a lot less of them around. You can use the (b)Food Dryer(/b) to convert (b)Raw Meat(/b) to (b)Cured Meat(/b), which lasts a lot longer. (b)Berries(/b), (b)Fruit(/b) and (b)Nuts(/b). Available mostly in summer only, but some also in autumn. They don't last for long, but they are a good food to eat seasonally, so you can save non perishable foods for the winter. (b)Pulses(/b). Available in summer, they require the right harvesting tools and technology to be processed. They last for a reasonable amount of time. (b)Grain(/b). It lasts for an extremely long time, but requires processing to be eaten: First needs to be converted into (b)Flour(/b), then into (b)Bread(/b). This makes it quite labor intensive. People will try to eat the foods that are about to perish first.
Welfare

A measure of how well your settlement is doing. Depends on your people's (b)stats(/b), (b)clothing(/b) and also on the (b)food surplus(/b). If welfare is high (b)migrants(/b) will come to your settlement, the higher it is the more frequently they will arrive. Welfare also affects the (b)birth rate(/b) in your settlement.
Prestige

A measure of how well known your settlement is. Depends on your (b)population(/b), (b)buildings(/b) and (b)technology(/b). If prestige is high (b)migrants(/b) and (b)traders(/b) will come more frequently to your settlement. A good way to increase your settlement's (b)prestige(/b) is by constructing (b)megalithic(/b) structures.
Conditions

Humans can be affected by conditions such as (b)diseases(/b) or (b)infections(/b). These are triggered from (b)going hungry(/b) repeatedly, or (b)sustaining injuries(/b). When a person has a condition it's health will decrease for a given amount of time, if it reaches zero the person will die. Survival chances are partly random and party based on how healthy the individual is.

Customizable Panels

By pressing the (b)+(/b) buttons on the top part of the screen, you can (b)customize the info panels(/b). You can get the UI to display the most (b)relevant information(/b) depending on your current situation.
Transportation

(b)Transports(/b) will greatly increase the efficiency of your settlement. Some resources, like (b)Logs(/b), (b)Stone(/b), (b)Copper Ore(/b), (b)Tin Ore(/b) or (b)Iron Ore(/b) are heavy and difficult to carry around. Only adults can transport these, at a very slow speed, one at a time, and with a penalty to morale. (b)Sledges(/b) and (b)Carts(/b) solve this problem, they allow you to transport several (b)heavy resources(/b) at a time a lot more efficiently.
Fuel

In order to (b)cook food(/b) and stay warm you need to fuel your (b)Hearths(/b), (b)Huts(/b), (b)Roundhouses(/b) and (b)Ovens(/b). You can use (b)Sticks(/b) or (b)Logs(/b) for this purpose. Your people will automatically refuel all structures unless you disable it in each structure.
Structures
You can build many different structures in your settlement. Initially only a few are available, but you will unlock many more as the game progresses.
Resources
You will need to manage a variety of Resources to keep your settlement running. Most resources will decay and eventually become unusable, so you will need to continuously produce them.
Techs

Techs allow you to produce (b)more resources(/b), build (b)new structures(/b), and (b)move forward(/b) through the ages. To research and unlock new techs, you need to spend knowledge points in the tech panel. You earn (b)knowledge points(/b) when doing actions such as hunting animals, gathering resources, or achieving higher populations. You can only unlock a Tech if you've previously unlocked it's (b)prerequisite techs(/b) and the (b)era(/b) it belongs to. To unlock a new Era you need to unlock it's Era Tech, which requires twice as many Knowledge points to unlock.
Animals

Animals are the source of many key goods, such as (b)Raw Meat(/b), (b)Bones(/b), or (b)Raw Skins(/b). In (b)winter(/b) most animals will hibernate or migrate to warmer climates, so there will be less of them around. Once you research the right domestication techs, you can capture young animals in order to breed them yourself.
Transports
Transports allow people to (b)carry resources(/b) much faster than they would otherwise do. Specialized transports are also required to move (b)Megaliths(/b).
Structures that provide shelter for people or animals.
Structures to store resources.
Structures to process resources.
Structures to help protect your settlement against (b)raiders(/b) or dangerous (b)predators(/b).
Structures for mining and processing metals.

Structures that improve your people's (b)Morale(/b). When low on (b)Morale(/b), your people will visit a spiritual structure in order to recover it. Note that a person can not use the same type of structure too often, so it is important to build variety of these.
Structures that improve transport efficiency.
A basic shelter

The earliest and most basic accommodation available, people can (b)rest(/b) and (b)shelter(/b) from the cold in it. It deteriorates quickly and needs periodic maintenance. It can be built from the (b)Paleolithic(/b).
A hut with a thatched roof

A construction made out of (b)Mud(/b) with a thatched (b)Straw(/b) roof, people can (b)rest(/b), (b)shelter(/b) and (b)cook(/b) in it. It is more durable than a (b)Tent(/b) and can house more people. It require the (b)Thatching(/b) tech in order to be built.
A circular stone house

A construction made of (b)Stone(/b) with a thatched (b)Straw(/b) roof, people can (b)rest(/b), (b)shelter(/b) and (b)cook(/b) in it. It is more durable than a (b)Hut(/b) and can house more people. It requires the (b)Masonry(/b) tech in order to be built.
A place to keep domestic animals
A place for (b)domestic animals(/b) to (b)shelter(/b) in winter and be fed and watered. It needs periodic maintenance.
A basic storage structure
A large tent built for storing and (b)preserving resources(/b) for longer. It deteriorates quickly and needs periodic maintenance. It can be built from the (b)Paleolithic(/b).
A place to store Sticks and Logs
A place to stack (b)Sticks(/b) or (b)Logs(/b), rather than using residence or other storage structures, which wastes valuable space.
A place to store Straw
A place to store (b)Straw(/b), rather than using residence or other storage structures, which wastes valuable space.
A hut to store and preserve resources

A large construction made out of (b)Mud(/b) with a thatched (b)Straw(/b) roof, where resources can be stored and preserved for longer. It is more durable than a (b)Storage Tent(/b) and can store more resources for longer. Requires the (b)Thatching(/b) tech in order to be built.
A structure to preserve food

A raised hut, purpose built to keep food dry and preserved for (b)as long as possible(/b). Granaries are reasonably durable, but they need repairing from time to time. Requires the (b)Thatching(/b) tech in order to be built.
A place to store Flint, Stone or Ores
A place to store (b)Flint(/b), (b)Stone(/b) or (b)ores(/b), rather than using residence or other storage structures, which wastes valuable space.
A stone house to store and preserve resources

A large construction made out of (b)Stone(/b) with a thatched (b)Straw(/b) roof, where resources can be stored and preserved for longer. It is more durable than a (b)Storage Hut(/b) and can store more resources for longer. Requires the (b)Masonry(/b) tech in order to be built.
A place to cook, make bread and socialize
A common place where to cook food and make bread.
A place to create tools and clothing

The Crafter is the main production structure in the (b)Stone Age(/b). In it your people can create all the (b)tools(/b) and (b)clothing(/b) they will need in the early eras. It is a good idea to use (b)automated production(/b) (by right clicking on an item) and (b)resource limits(/b) in order to avoid to have to manually craft tools every time you need them.
A place to dry skins
A structure where your people will transform (b)Raw Skins(/b) into (b)Dry Skins(/b), that are more durable and usable.
A place to dry food
A structure where (b)Raw Meat(/b) and (b)Fish(/b) can be processed into (b)Cured Meat(/b) and (b)Dry Fish(/b).
A rock to crush Grain into Flour
A rock to crush (b)Grain(/b) into (b)Flour(/b). This is quite a labor intensive process.
A place to make Leather from Raw Skins
A place where (b)Raw Skins(/b) can be treated with (b)Tannin(/b) in order to make (b)Leather(/b).
A hole in the ground to extract water
Wells provide settlements with a steady source of (b)Water(/b), they can be placed within the settlement's walls in order to avoid people having to go to the nearest river or lake.
An underground structure to increase Flint extraction
(b)Increases(/b) the amount of (b)Flint(/b) that can be extracted from a deposit.
A place to make cloth
A place where (b)Linen(/b) and (b)Wool(/b) are woven to create cloth, that can then be used to make outfits.
A place to create clothing
A place where outfits are made from (b)Linen Cloth(/b) and (b)Wool Cloth(/b).
A place to brew Beer
A facility where your people can make (b)Beer(/b) from (b)Grain(/b) and (b)Water(/b). (b)Beer(/b) increases morale in your settlement.
A place to crush grain using hydropower
A place where to efficiently crush large quantities of (b)Grain(/b) into (b)Flour(/b) using hydropower.
A communal oven to bake Bread in large quantities
A place where to efficiently bake large quantities of (b)Bread(/b).
A place to make miscellaneous tools
A place to make tools from the (b)Copper Age(/b) onwards. This structure in combination with the (b)Metalsmith(/b) or (b)Blacksmith(/b) serves as replacement for the (b)Crafter(/b).
An underground structure to increase Copper Ore extraction
An underground excavation that (b)increases(/b) the amount of (b)Copper Ore(/b) that can be extracted from a deposit.
An underground structure to increase Tin Ore extraction
An underground excavation that (b)increases(/b) the amount of (b)Tin Ore(/b) that can be extracted from a deposit.
An underground structure to increase Iron Ore extraction
An underground excavation that (b)increases(/b) the amount of (b)Iron Ore(/b) that can be extracted from a deposit.
A place to make Charcoal from wood
A place to make (b)Charcoal(/b) from wood. (b)Charcoal(/b) is then used in the furnaces to smelt ores into metals.
A place to smelt Copper and Tin Ores into Copper and Bronze
A basic furnace where (b)Charcoal(/b) is used in order to attain the high temperatures required to smelt (b)Copper Ore(/b) and (b)Tin Ore(/b) into (b)Copper(/b) and (b)Bronze(/b).
A place to make Copper and Bronze tools
A place to create (b)Copper(/b) and (b)Bronze(/b) tools and weapons. Note that only one person can work in it at a time, so you will usually need a few of these.
A place to smelt Iron Ore into Iron and Steel
An advanced furnace, where very high temperatures can be reached in order to smelt (b)Iron Ore(/b) into (b)Iron(/b) and (b)Steel(/b).
A place to make Iron and Steel tools
A place to create (b)Iron(/b) and (b)Steel(/b) tools and weapons. Note that only one person can work in it at a time, so you will usually need a few of these.
Simple wooden structure to protect the settlement
Simple wooden structure to protect the settlement. It's made from (b)Logs(/b) and offers a reasonable level of protection.
Simple wooden gate, to control access to your settlement
A simple wooden gate, that can resist attacks for a reasonable amount of time.
Basic tower, from which to shoot at enemies
The most basic defense tower. Up to 2 people can shelter in it and (b)shoot(/b) at incoming enemies. They require periodic (b)repairs(/b) and maintenance.
A sturdy Stone wall to protect the settlement
A durable (b)Stone(/b) wall, that offers the highest level of protection available against intruders.
A metal reinforced gate
A gate (b)reinforced(/b) with (b)metal(/b) in order to increase its resistance against attacks.
A reinforced defense tower
A reinforced defense tower. Up to 3 people can shelter in it and shoot at incoming enemies. Guard Towers require periodic repairs and maintenance.
A structure in memory of the dead
A structure in memory of the dead that your people can visit in order to recover (b)Morale(/b).
A structure to honor nature
A tall, powerful symbol of both the tribe itself and its relation with nature. Your people can use it to recover (b)Morale(/b).
A standing Megalith
A large standing (b)Megalith(/b). Your people can use it to recover (b)Morale(/b).
A large monument made of several stones supporting a bigger rock
A stone chamber consisting of several supporting pillars, and one or more stones placed on top. It increases your settlement's (b)prestige(/b) and boosts people's (b)Morale(/b).
The ultimate megalithic structure
A large structure composed by several (b)Megaliths(/b) arranged in a circle. It greatly increases your settlement's (b)prestige(/b) and provides a boost for your people's (b)Morale(/b).
A structure to allow easier crossing of rivers
A structure in order to ease the (b)crossing of rivers(/b). This is especially useful for (b)Sledges(/b) and (b)Carts(/b) as otherwise they have to cross via the nearest ford.

Tools are required to perform certain tasks such as hunting, butchering, mining, fishing, or harvesting. Your people will automatically fetch the right tool for the job before doing it. Each tool has a series of attributes that indicate how suitable the tool is to perform certain tasks: (b)Fighting.(/b) Hand to hand combat. (b)Hunting.(/b) Killing animals or ranged combat. (b)Butchering.(/b) Butchering dead animals and extracting their resources. (b)Fishing.(/b) Extracting fish from rivers or lakes. (b)Harvesting.(/b) Harvesting cereals or pulses. (b)Mining.(/b) Extracting ores from deposits or mines. (b)Woodcutting.(/b) Cut down trees. Fighting and hunting attributes affect damage dealt in combat, other attributes affect the speed at which the task is done.

Clothing offers your people protection from cold, increases welfare and reduces damage sustained in combat. (b)Skins(/b) and (b)Wool(/b) outfits protect people up to freezing temperatures. It is (b)critical(/b) that you have one of these per inhabitant. When it is warm your people will prefer to wear (b)Leather(/b) or (b)Linen(/b) outfits, these increase (b)welfare(/b) levels and offer slight protection in combat. A typical way to ensure you have enough clothing is to set outfits to continuous production in the (b)Crafter(/b) or (b)Outfitter(/b) structures and having a resource limit set of 100%. When the temperature drops below the level of protection clothing offers, the temperature of the person will start to drop, at this point they will have to seek (b)shelter(/b) or they will die of (b)hypothermia(/b).
Resources that can be consumed to recover (b)Nutrition(/b) and (b)Hydration(/b) levels.
Resources used to (b)craft(/b) or (b)build(/b) other resources or structures.
General purpose cutting tool

Fish that has been dried. Lasts for a long time

The seeds of many types of legume fruits. They need to be (b)cooked(/b) before they can be eaten.
A nutritious drink obtained from domestic (b)Goats(/b) or (b)Cattle(/b).

To capture a wild animal you need to select a young animal of the right type and then click on the capture button. Make sure to have enough capacity in your (b)Stables(/b), otherwise the animals will die in winter.
Unlocks the creation of (b)tools(/b) made using animal (b)bones(/b), which are effective for certain tasks.

Allows you to make (b)Slings(/b), which are basic hunting tools.

Unlocks the domestication of (b)Dogs(/b). Dogs will slowly come to the settlement and will help you protect it.

Unlocks (b)polished(/b) stone tools in the (b)Crafter(/b).
Unlocks the (b)Mesolithic(/b) era, and also the ability to (b)transport(/b) and (b)store Water(/b). This is a lot more efficient than having people going to the water source every time.
Unlocks the creation of (b)Bows(/b), which are the best hunting tool available in the (b)Stone Age(/b).

Unlocks the construction of basic (b)defensive structures(/b) that can be used to protect your settlement against (b)raiders(/b) and (b)predators(/b) in order to minimize the loss of life.
Unlocks the construction of (b)Reinforced Gates(/b) and (b)Guard Towers(/b). These are more durable than their wooden counterparts, and in the case of the (b)Guard Tower(/b) can hold more people.

It allows you to (b)plant(/b) and (b)harvest cereals(/b), unlocking the (b)Neolithic(/b) era. It and dramatically (b)increases(/b) the amount of (b)people(/b) you can reliably (b)feed(/b) every year. This is one of the most important techs in the history of mankind.

Allows you to build (b)Bridges(/b).

Allows you to plant (b)fruit trees(/b).

Domestic animals provide a variety of benefits to your settlement: (b)protection(/b), (b)food(/b), (b)resources(/b) and (b)muscle power(/b). You can obtain domestic animals by (b)purchasing(/b) them from traders, or by (b)domesticating young(/b) individuals of the equivalent wild variant. Animals need to be sheltered in winter, and be provided with (b)Water(/b) and (b)Straw(/b). If there is no (b)Straw(/b) available, you can feed them with (b)Grain(/b). Note that (b)Dogs(/b), as well as (b)Donkeys(/b) or (b)Horses(/b) that are (b)attached to transports(/b), don't need shelter or food in winter. Adult females will get pregnant and give (b)birth(/b) to new animals as long as there is an adult or old male around. Note that your people will automatically (b)slaughter(/b) any domestic animals that are (b)too old(/b), even if they are below the limit.
Wild animals inhabit the land and for the most part (b)avoid humans(/b). Predators will pose a threat if they are (b)very hungry(/b), or if they feel (b)threatened(/b).

Once the (b)Dog Domestication(/b) tech is researched, dogs will keep on coming to the village at a steady rate, depending on your population. They eat the leftovers from the humans, so they don't require to be fed or given shelter.

(b)Horses(/b) are used primarily to pull (b)Carts(/b), but they can also be slaughtered to obtain meat.

Healthy (b)adults(/b) are faster and (b)tougher(/b), so they require better tools or more hunters to be dealt with effectively. Large herbivores will provide your people with large amounts of vital (b)resources(/b). However they are used to defending themselves against predators, and (b)might retaliate(/b) if attacked. Approach them with care.
